Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: No. Never. The blood stays on the blade, son.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: Did you bring the boy for a charm, Priest?

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: No, Jack. For a baptism.

Speaker: rabbit warrior
Dialogue: We'll send a few across the river today, Priest.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: What's the fight?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: The Dead Rabbits against the Native Americans, same as ever. But it'll all be settled today.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Are you Native or Rabbit?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Looks alright. I'll stand by you, then.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I suppose there's to be a fight.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Derry?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Donnegal. Name's Monk Eastman.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: And you want to fight, Mr. Eastman?

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: lf there's money in it.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Fight for the Natives. They have a proper war chest.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: Well, I might at that. But I thought I'd ask you first, seeing as how I'm not quite a Native American myself.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Let's see your skills, and we'll talk of payment later.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: Fine. But if you like what you see, pay me double. Monk turns to the door with the grace of a dancer and delivers a SHATTERING kick, sending it flying off its hinges. Clear white LIGHT streams in, and we see Monk Eastman plain for the first time: a huge man, in stature and girth, wearing a small DERBY that intentionally makes his head look even bigger.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Stand with us then.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Bill Poole! on whose challenge are we assembled? A MAN in a leather duster  steps forward. He is young, lean and fierce. And then there are his eyes. They do not match. One is real. The other is a huge, bulging PEARL upon which has been engraved, instead of a pupil, a full-color portrait of the AMERICAN EAGLE.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Bene.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: But this time can you bear to look on the glory when it comes, Bill? Can you see it clear with your single eye?

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: It wasn't God who touched your eye.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: I don't expect a death blow from your hand, Butcher. Let's have at it.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Say it out and quick, before spring gets here.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Prepare to receive the Lord.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: I run with you! I'm one of you! Born a Native American from the blood of five generations!

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: Can't..can't cross the river... with steel through my heart. Amsterdam looks around. None of the Rabbits makes a move. This is clearly something he is meant to do himself. Amsterdam grabs the tortoise handle of the knife, PULLS on it. Vallon tries not to cry out. The knife does not move. Amsterdam tries again. He can't budge the knife. Vallon MOANS. Nearly wild, Amsterdam PULLS with all his strength. Vallon SCREAMS in agony. Amsterdam is pulling so hard he raises his father's back four inches off the ground. Still the knife will not move. Vallon passes out from the pain. Now, finally, someone steps forward: Monk Eastman. He leans over but Amsterdam, berserk with grief, pushes him away, turns back to his father, and, with a last desperate pull, DRAWS the knife from his father's heart. He throws it on the ground. Monk picks it up, wipes the blade on his arm, closes the knife and hands it to Amsterdam.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: That's yours, rightfully. Now Monk leans over the lifeless body and reaches inside Vallon's coat, REMOVING some money.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: And this is mine. Only what's owed. Use the rest for funeral.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No! He tries to shove Monk away from his father, when the Native Warrior intervenes.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: It's fair.

Speaker: vallon
Dialogue: ... honor me... think of me ... don't never look away. Vallon convulses and DIES. Amsterdam shakes him to revive him.

Speaker: rabbit woman
Dialogue: Take the body. Bring the boy. Several RABBITS take a step or two forward, but Amsterdam springs up at them, like an animal.

Speaker: rabbit warrior
Dialogue: Come an, lad. Therels nothing to be done now.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Get away! Get away!

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: Leave him be. He's his to mourn.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Where's your family, sonny?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: My mother's just there.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: On the trip, her insides all broke up. She wasn't dead and there was three others fighting for her bed.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: And your father? Where's he, then?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I never knew him.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Where all those streets come together right ahead is the true Five Points. But most speak of the Five Points and mean anywhere between the Battery and the Bowery. Although the night's cold, the streets are jammed. WHORES painted like carnival Gypsies sell themselves to any man sober enough to stand up. SOUNDS of laughter and combat filter out from garish SALOONS like the Little Naples, the Hell Hole, the Egyptian Hall. In the midst of all this highlife are BEGGARS and the SICKLY, looking for charity, scrounging garbage in the street. An INDIGENT battles a CRIPPLE for a meager scrap of faod. A richly dressed WOMAN, riding by in a carriage, hides her eyes by raising a HUGE BOUQUET OF FLOWERS in front of her face.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Streets hereabouts are lively of an evening. The city comes here to sport. But there's places to put up a boy on his own.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: And those? What are those?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Well, those. Those are, as you might say, a sort of...

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: ... sort of whatnot.

Speaker: transvestite
Dialogue: Say, policeman. I'll buy your bonny friend.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: We passed the plate amongst ourselves. Come up with enough ned to carry all this, and carry you a while, too.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Where will my father rest?

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: Potters Field, with everyone else.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: My father won't be buried with everyone else. He'll lie separate in fresh ground, facing east.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: What difference where he faces?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: He'll face east for the second coming of Christ.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: Fine, son. When Jesus gets to the Battery you show Him the way from there.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: Not tonight, Maggie, we got...

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Any ned in your pocket, sir.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: She sing sweet as she looks?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Pure celestial, sir.  Go on, Jenny.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: No, Jen, the other.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Mr. Tweed would like a word, Mr. Cornelius.  Tweed of Tammany.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: In your office. At your pleasure, of course.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Mr. Cornelius. With a view like this I'm surprised the dead can rest in peace.

Speaker: cornelius
Dialogue: Is there anything I can...

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Yes. A favor.

Speaker: cornelius
Dialogue: Happy to serve, Mr. Tweed.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Excellent. Lend me something.

Speaker: cornelius
Dialogue: Oh, I don't know what I could ...

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: I believe in form and appearance, you see. Just like yourself, sir. And I believe in law, and the power of example. Our city is a lawless wilderness, sir. I'm asking you to help chasten it.

Speaker: cornelius
Dialogue: A matter of civic duty, then.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: And civic pride. I want you to help me set an example.  I only need to borrow one of your clients.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: Me? Oh, I don't know. All that talk of blood loyalty makes me quake. I'll spill blood when the price is right. But blood for ceremony? I prefer holy communion.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: Not mine. Not now, and not any time after.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: Come on, boyo. I'll put you up tonight.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'll do for myself, Jack.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: You can't.  There's no mistaking you're his son.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What's the cost to bury my father proud and proper?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Firewood?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: It's a penny the load.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Later.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Help me.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Come on! Help me, goddamn it!

Speaker: crusher
Dialogue: Ask the boy.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I paid Cornelius for my father to rest in honor. He told me I had to wait on a permit, but he only wanted time to...

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: The boy...

Speaker: prisoner
Dialogue: Ain't his first Tombs trip.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: What do they call you?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Amsterdam.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: Your full name.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Vallon.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: First name?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I told you.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: Address?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Got none.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: I'll put city. Now what's your age?  Maybe twelve. Got a family?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No more.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: Well, where was they from when you had one?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: City.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: Disrobe.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: What's the charge, Asbury?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Theft. Assault. Creating a ...

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: Through that door there.  And don't stand too near no one else.

Speaker: visitor one
Dialogue: Ought to be served in a trough, properly. Will you try some?

Speaker: artist
Dialogue: Probably. What is it?

Speaker: visitor one
Dialogue: All-Sorts. It's made of all that's poured and not drunk, and any they can salvage that's spilt.

Speaker: visitor
Dialogue: Your health.

Speaker: gamemaster
Dialogue: Alright, gents and ladies, your bets now on Towser against the vermin, the count to beat is ten rodents in three minutes.

Speaker: guard 2
Dialogue: You get to live private until they come from the orphan's asylum. On account of your tender years.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Let me see! I don't believe it.

Speaker: friend
Dialogue: No! It's a danger.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Oh come on! It's not.  Then tell me where you got it.

Speaker: friend
Dialogue: From some man. He took me in his carriage. He only wanted to do something to me fast.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: friend
Dialogue: I didn't understand.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Would he do the same with me?

Speaker: friend
Dialogue: I won't tell you if he's around again.  He's my secret.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Better keep it more careful, then.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: I don't know...

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: You're a lunatic to come here like...

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I do understand, yes.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: But you don't understand at all.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: There's a whole city to share and all you see is your own narrow streets.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Yes, alright. Gladly. It's all blackjack jobs and panel games and killings for a fiver.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: As far as it goes.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: But we're talking about different things, Bill. You describe the present. I see the possibilities. Look to the future. There is so much more.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: There's things demanding to be done that no police force can do, not even an obedient one. There's contributions from every dive and brothel. Loyalties to be secured and debts to be collected.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: ... beside Tammany... in the performance of these civic obligations. And for a satisfactory... I'm prepared even to say equitable... financial participation. It's not the sort of responsibility the founding fathers might have recognized. But then, the founding fathers never imagined the city New York has become.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: We'd like to. I do miss it. But it's wiser for men in the public life to give an appearance of probity.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, no. The appearance of law must be upheld, especially while it's being broken.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Perhaps not within the Points. But the smart man could go higher.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Anyone inside?

Speaker: onlooker
Dialogue: No, praise God, but all we own...

Speaker: onlooker
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Waiting on reinforcements.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: That's not them. It's only the Black Jokes. Seems your fire interrupted their festivities.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: May I point out that the building is burning to ashes?

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Certainly. And may I then remind you, Pocahontas, that this entire area is the province of the Americus company, and you will kindly keep your distance. Impasse. The rival Fire Companies size each other up and start toward each other. The building continues to burn. Tweed remains regal and unperturbed atop the fire plug. As the two COMPANIES are about to close with each other, a second BELL sounds. Tweed's "reinforcements" have arrived: the Native Americans, led by Bill The Butcher. They PILE OFF the wagons before the horses halt. Now the Black Joke Co. is outnumbered, and it FALLS BACK. As the Crowd CHEERS, Tweed takes the bucket off the fire plug.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Alright, boys! To work!

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Next building over, boys! Mustn't let it spread!

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Another proud night for Tammany, Bill.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Just tell them...  ... to take enough to share. And not to steal so in the open.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Jesus! Boss says to tell you to fight the fire from the front and loot out the back.

Speaker: tearful woman
Dialogue: The Black Joke could have saved my house!

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Black Joke had no business here, Madam.

Speaker: tearful woman
Dialogue: Their business was to save my house!

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Tammany's your business. When we're here to call upon there's no need of other. We understand loss, Madam, and take care of our own.

Speaker: second guard
Dialogue: It's Blackwell's Island certain now, boyo.

Speaker: third guard
Dialogue: Are you hurting? Let's hear you!

Speaker: second guard
Dialogue: There's nothing funny, boyo! You been beat and turned back four times now.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: But every time you bring me back... you got to come further to catch me.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Hard starboard, Shang! Hard starboard!

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: I told you forget that sailor stuff! Which way's star... Too late. Their Ticket craft crashes into the side with enough force to make a LOUD THUMP and to send Shang sprawling.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Why don't we just knock on their front door?

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Spread out and make for the cabin. Moving slowly, the boys FAN OUT and move toward the cabin at the far end of the deck. Johnny stays close to Shang, holding onto the shipls rail for support.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Nothing. Looks picked clean.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Bill and the Natives must have got here first.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: What ...

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: That'll bring the Harbor cops for sure.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Wait! Take him. If he's still alive he's good for ransom!

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Hels dead as Good Friday, can't you...

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Then we'll take Bill the Butcher's cleaver and sell the body to the medical students. They'll go five dollars for it anyway.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Come on. We'll get something out of this.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: The Harbors!

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: We can't go back to Corlears Hook, they'll be watching...

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: We'll make for Blackwells.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: And which way's that through this fog?

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: Should have asked them directions as they drifted by, Shang.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: You'd have liked that, wouldn't you Coal Face? You're the only one they'd miss in the dark.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Let's quiet, or we'll all be found out!

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Alright. We lay up here till first light. Then we run back across the river.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: River pirates!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Head straight out, then turn for the current.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Figured you for dead.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Close enough.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: This is my crew. And welcome to join, if you've the mettle. We're river pirates and quick thieves and street brawlers...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You're lost.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Yeah? You've no business saying anything against us! Do you know how much you cost us? You know how much that body's worth?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I doubt it's worth the water it's floating in.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Fifteen dollars! Fifteen dollars from them medical ghouis.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'll make it back for you whatever it is, once we're in the city. Just keep sailing, or we're all done for.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: He was in his prime. He'd have fetched thirty dollars easy.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: You're as flat as Broadway going north. We can't run the river no more. We're poaching the Natives and the Harbor cops are looking for us.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: The cops can go to blazes. Who cares about them?

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Youlre all sand when it comes to cops, Shang. But do you have the sand to go against the Natives?

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: It ain't the time to go against the Natives. We've got to build first. Then we go.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: If we go like we did in the river, all of us'll sink.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Does Shang have the sand to ever go against the Natives?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I don't know. He acts like it.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: If he only acts, held be better on the stage.  Like her.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Jenny Everdeane. Shang turned her into the best bludget in the Points.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Shes his mort, is she, as well as his best provider?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Yeah. But Jenny says she's anyone's she chooses.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: That's the prize of the month. Spice Islands silk.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: You'll learn our way if you're going to be one of us, Amsterdam.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Every one of us gives a portion of all they steal to the gang. Morts more than men, being morts.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Yeah? And why is that?

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Because morts have more resources. Men can work only on their feet, but a mort can turn out on her back.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I mean, why give at all? Why don't they keep for themselves?

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: If you think there's something off about my way of running things, you got no place in this gang.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I got no place anyway, and you got no gang. This ain't a gang, no matter what you say. It's a mob.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: It's all your play now, Shang. Maybe you can set him right.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: I've come for my due and proper, Shang.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: As agreed, then, Jack. Refreshment?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Still smiling, are you?

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: It's the young Vallon, is it? I hardly recognized you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I hardly knew you under that hat, Jack.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: There. For your respect.

Speaker: happy jack
Dialogue: Anybody else? Any number at all, come on.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Is that sand we've just seen?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: It's politics.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I've got my own way to go, why don't you find yours?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Because your way's different, and I want to see where it goes.  Unless you say otherwise. Amsterdam shrugs and keep walking.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You act like you have something in mind, like you know every day what you'll be doing the next. Me, I don't figure on tomorrow.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Well, if you shut up a while maybe it'd come on its own.  Now what the hell's that?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Oh that's heaven.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: The city shut down the Brewery as unfit to live and Tammany gave it over to this minister.

Speaker: amsterdan
Dialogue: What's Tammany?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Why Tammany ... you don't know? Tammany makes the city run. A political organization that's like... like the Native Americans, only ranging over the whole city.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: They seem like the law, but they got a way of acting outside the law. Anything that happens in this city, on the straight or on the sly, Tammany's a part of, and Boss Tweedls the heart of Tammany.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: They're the best gang there is.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: So if Tammany's the best, go with Tammany. What are you running with this mob for?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: 'Cause they're more my size for now. With Tammany, you got to do something large, something that makes them take notice of you.

Speaker: amsterdan
Dialogue: You're better oft without their notice. You can run free, work your own schemes.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: But if your schemes have size, you need size to bring them off.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What are you thinking?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Let me in if you ever get it figured.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'll go on my own from here.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: I dread city stimmers. They bring illness and beget vermin.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: We can't have every citizen of the Five Points boxed up like cargo.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: But the season is vicious, and I must take thought of our constituents. Mr. Gleason, I'd like you to shake hands with Mr. Barnett Baff...

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: A friend and owner of an estimable carting service. Work out an arrangement whereby the citizenry can receive the benefit of Mr. Gleason's wondrous elixir outside this excellent box. At a cost, Mr. Gleason, of how much the barrel ...

Speaker: gleason
Dialogue: Oh, perhaps twenty-five dollars.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: ...and how much, Mr. Baff, for haulage and distribution...

Speaker: baff
Dialogue: The same again. At least.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: At least. That's a price of fifty dollars. And greedy, low piracy at that  But a price that Tammany, in its generosity, will meet. Merely submit a bill for a hundred. We'll each have half. And I'll retain this box for further experiment. Hello, Bill.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Bolt the door.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Scotchy Lavelle's gone wrong in his accounts.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Not good enough to rake thirty percent of our share from Sparrow's and use it for his own.  You got to give him over, Bill.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: Alright then. What about Charles McGloin? He's running a panel game off to one side. Did you know that?  Charles McGloin will do.

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: I'll set the trial for Friday.

Speaker: assistant hangman
Dialogue: Those interested in the effects of the condemned please come forward.

Speaker: assistant hangman
Dialogue: What am I bid for this coat? A coat of some wear but excellent cut... containing a rather remarkable pocket silk...

Speaker: hangman
Dialogue: A quarter, thank you. Do I hear fifty cents? Fifty cents?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Here. Just for the silk.

Speaker: warden
Dialogue: Do you have any last remarks, Charles McGloin?

Speaker: mcgloin
Dialogue: Not from under this hood I don't.

Speaker: mcgloin
Dialogue: I never struck a foul blow or turned a card and may God greet me as a friend!

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I hope you won't think me rude if I speak.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: No, sir. You look a proper Gentleman down to the ground.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Well, I wouldn't want you to think me forward, you see.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Does it matter to you what I think?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Well, I might like it to.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I mean, if you would like.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I might like, sir. But I can't say now.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Because this is my stop.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: But I'll never see you again.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I come every Thursday to the Tombs to see my father.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I'll look for you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: May I walk with you a little, then?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Are you a spy, then?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Got no one to spy for. I'm an appreciator, you might say.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Appreciator of what?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: A good touch.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Don't bother with the chat. If you want me, we come to a business arrangement. lf the terms is right, then I decide how you suit me. Then I do it or not.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Just take a minute, I was Just...

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: What's it to you?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Give him this.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: How'd you come by this?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I got my own touch.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Are you making me a present, or making an Arrangement?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It's your rules, right? So you decide.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Pretty slim cut for a hanging day. Where'd you get that?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: From Amsterdam.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: It don't suit you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Commissioner Brunt said to spare you nothing concerning conditions.

Speaker: citizen
Dialogue: Nothing but our safety, of course.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: All's snug around Paradise Square in my company, squire. See there.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Tammany makes the streets nanitary, I make 'am safe.

Speaker: woman citizen
Dialogue: Even against them?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Against them especially. Let me demonstrate.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We'll be back for this at our leisure.

Speaker: woman citizen
Dialogue: You dare leave it here?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Safe as a vault, lady. Since all knows it's mine.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: You know that's Jack's.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: So what?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: If it's free, how come we pay so much? Wo shouldn't pay for what's our due.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: We don't tight when we don't have to. It's not warring that counts. It's the living day to day.

Speaker: ansterdam
Dialogue: Is that right? Did I hear that correct? John, did we hear that correct?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: We heard the same.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: So then.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What'd you do to my watch, you dirty little bastard...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Hands won't be so quick in future.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I have word for you from who did it. You're to meet him at Sparrow's Chinese Pagoda.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: All right, step out, you yellow...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Hello, Happy Jack. I'm the one you're looking for.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Then you're marked for dead.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: I gave no order for this.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Never mind giving orders. What were you giving this for? SHANG I'm calling you out, Amsterdam.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I got this at the hanging. It was Charles McGloin's. Everybody here saw you take it from Jenny. What was MCGloin doing with it? What'd you give it to him for?

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: I didn't give it to him. Why would I give it to him?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I gaw you give it to him. Last week, behind the Old Brewery.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: He's gone flat. I got no reason to trade with the Native Americans.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What about stepping up in the world, as it were, and leaving the rest of us behind. There's a reason. Making a separate arrangement for yourself with the one Native so stupid and luckless that he got hung. That's you to the ground, Shang.

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Who believes what he's saying? Can any of you believe what he's saying?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Bene. We'll see. Any of you that believes I did proper by Happy Jack Mulraney tonight, stand beside me. Any of you that still likes Shang's way with the cops, and Shang's way with the Natives, go to him.  Or should we settle right now, you and me, and just see which of us is left standing?

Speaker: shang
Dialogue: Let see where they stand.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What's your pleasure, Shang?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: This mob ever have a proper name?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: We was called after Shang when we was named at all.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: We're the Dead Rabbits from now. They were the best. They were history. They were legend, and we'll live up to them.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What's this then?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Payment for the silk.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You were waiting for me out here, weren't you?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Maybe I was, yeah.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You was that sure of me?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Sure enough to wait, anyway. Waiting don't cost nothing.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: It don't do to be sure. I could go away just as easy.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Alright.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I'll say when I want to, not you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Stay then.  One way or another, I get what I want.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Yeah. If it was just a shag you wanted.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You're a gypsy, are you, come to tell my fortune? Go ahead then. Tell me what I'm wanting.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You got blood in your eye for someone.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It's just I can't look away, that's all.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Who from?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Bill Poole.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You better get someone else in your sights. No one's ever taken him.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: 'Cause he's mine, that's why. I'll take his one eye, and then the rest of him, piece by small piece.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You have a plan for this? You going to raise a militia? I'll wager Bill the Butcher don't even know about you or care if he does.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: He'll know about me soon enough.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: And after the Butcher?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Is that so?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You'll be in love with me.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Love you? You just had me. You can have a mort any time you want. So why look for more than that.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: That's taking love, not giving it. I want it to be just you and me, no one else for either.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: 'Cause none of us means nothing in life except one to the other.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I don't know I want to mean something, to you or anybody. Can there be good in that?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: We'll see.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: It'll take a while if we do. If we ever do.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: And what about the meantime?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Meantime's business.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: The potato is a thick vegetable. Heavy. Meaty. Comes out of the ground dirty and stays that way unless you scrub it and boil it to death!  We don't want to keep lem out of the country! We'll even give 'em a place at our table! But we ain't gonna vote 'em into office.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Any Irish hears that will be out for blood.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: The Irish is too busy building up Tammany. That's where their brains and muscle goes. Once they're inside with their cronies, they turn on their own outside. Tammany'd steal the air and rent the daylight if they could.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: We'd do the same.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Tammany earns better. That's the difference.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I ain't seen their ned yet.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You will at day's end, that's our arrangement. A quarter a voter, whether they're repeaters or not. I'm telling you, we got a square deal.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: It's sound, Amsterdam.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Yeah? Well, it's ned anyway. Just make sure you count it when we get it.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: It's just a day's job, we don't have to make it a life's work. We work for Tammany today and kill them tomorrow, if that's our pleasure.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: So we're politicians just for today.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Not for a minute. We're better than that. We're thieves.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I would never speak ill of a rival. I would never say that every Know-Nothing is a horse thief. It is my observation, however, that every horse thief is a Know-Nothing.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: The Know-Nothings are already finished, and there's four more hours at the polls yet.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Keep our men voting. Everybody works today. It's not a victory we need, Daniel. I want a triumph.

Speaker: repeater
Dialogue: I already voted once today. Cast for Tammany, by God, and Fernando Wood.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Once? Come here and do your duty.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Line up like soldiers!

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: They got no notion what you're talking about.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You explain their democratic right. Illl see they unterstand.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: I come to see if our counts square. You boys have made a remarkable showing....

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Who the hell's this?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: He's our Tammany man.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: ... remarkable...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Our own Tammany man. We are coming along. Happy to meet any friend of Johnny Siroccols.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Likewise. Pleasure to meet the best but one in the whole Five Points.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Best but one? Who's better?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Maybe nobody. But when the count's done the numbers will tell who's come out in front.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'm in no race. Just pay us what you owe.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Tonight. At the victory celebration.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Read what it says there, alongside the ruby...read it out ...

Speaker: tweed
Dialogue: A grand victory gift from the men of Tammany. Now, tell 'em what it means, Mayor Wood.

Speaker: wood
Dialogue: "Fortune favors the bold."

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: What do you think? Would that make a fit motto for our fair City?

Speaker: wood
Dialogue: Well, I could certainly see ...

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: We've got a motto.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: what is it?  Well, hell, let's get one we can remember. We're going to build a new City hall, we better have something to put over the front door. And Mayor, you'll make sure the Latin's right?

Speaker: bouncer
Dialogue: I don't know you, you don't enter.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Come on, what are you saying? If you don't know us now, you'll know us tomorrow and you'll be working for us next week.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Daniel Killoran knows us.

Speaker: bouncer
Dialogue: Oh he does?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: We work for him.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: The hell we do.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Tampen down, will you?

Speaker: bouncer
Dialogue: Why don't you all get the hell out of here and go fix on a story? Go on!

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: It's all right, Nat. They're saying the truth. They gave a good day's work for a good wage.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: A fine first showing. But second best.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Second, eh? You don't say so.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: It's no shame to be bested by veterans. The Native Americans always sweep the field.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: We count on them sure as mass comes an Sunday.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Did you know this? Is this some scheme of yours?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: No, I didn't have no idea ...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I was working the same side as the Natives? The Natives?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: That's only right. Bill the Butcher's our ambassador throughout the Points, as you might say. It's deemed an honor to work with him. Everyone knows Bill Poole, everyone fears him, everyone ...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I sure as hell don't fear him. And I sure as hell won't stand with him, or any who calls him one of theirs.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Well, if it's matter of personal honor, the money can only be a further insult. I have no wish to rile you further, so if you'll allow me...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Where is he? Where's Bill the Butcher?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Listen, buck. This is a Tammany night. If you and Bill Poole have matters to settle, you can do it any other time, any other place, I don't give a good dancing goddamn. But you do it here tonight and all the Five Points will be down on you like the righteous wrath of heaven. or you could, as the Book says, put away childish things. Join the celebration. Personally, I always find the least strenuous solution the most appealing. Don't you?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I got experience. It's the education I lack.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: And you heard I was a good teacher?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I don't listen to talk, I figure for myself. And I figured you'd be good at everything you did.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: And tonight I got the ned.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: And now what?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Now I'm ready for you. Unless there's an arrangement between you and Amsterdam.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Not to my thinking.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Amsterdam... listen up, Amsterdam...

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You going with me or him? It's my thinking matters here. You don't have to ask him nothing.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: How's the evening passing?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Fine. Why?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: 'Cause it's treating me fine too.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: This is no game, you and me. Don't go on like it's a game.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I said already, it's not a game. It's business.

Speaker: groper
Dialogue: How much will it cost?

Speaker: pagoda spectator
Dialogue: Watch this careful. I've never seen the like, not even in Barnum's Museum.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Mr. Poole!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Bill Poole!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: My compliments on your exhibition, sir.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It was like watching a dance.  You know me, sir.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No. A father.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Amsterdam.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Indeed.  And to my other name. Vallon. Will you drink to that?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Not worthy of you. Those dogs ain't worthy of you. You ain't worth what they feed on, and what they shit's too good for you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I got to give you something, Butcher. Something from my father.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: The Butcher'll kill him if we don't do something.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: It was Amsterdam's own doing. And it'll be our death too if we try to stop it.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: That's the truth.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: The truth is you don't give a damn about him.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Yeah, well, if he gave a damn about us he wouldn't have called out the Butcher in the first place.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: It's been a full evening's fun now, Butcher. It's enough.

Speaker: monk eastmkn
Dialogue: Well I'm the game warden, you might say. I'm telling you this buck's too young yet. Wait till he's aged for a proper kill.

Speaker: monk eastmkn
Dialogue: Just settle yourself Bill ...

Speaker: monk eastmkn
Dialogue: ... and let the merrymaking continue.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: It was his father took me in first, and it's thanks I'm returning now.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: This squares any debt. Get him out of here.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Come ahead, Bill. Unless you're wanting to shout me to death.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: If these two are going to combat, it aught to be a worthier occasion. And more rewarding for all.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I only wanted to thank you, Bill, for the customary good job today... and an equally bright future for us both.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Will you drink with me, Bill, as a friend? An honored friend.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: If there's one thing I can't abide, it's fighting for free.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Go easy! Go easy. It's over.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: He knew what he was doing, hitting you.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Let's get him up.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Therels too damn little of him left to know anything.

Speaker: don whiskerandos
Dialogue: Someone's here for you.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: That so? What's he look like?

Speaker: don whiskerandos
Dialogue: He looks pretty damned sorry.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Indeed.- Can I buy you a shave?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No thanks.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Face is too sore, eh? I understand.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No. I'm beholden enough to you as it is. I don't like to be beholden.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: We're all even, son. There's nothing more between us.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'd like it if there was.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Are you proposing employment?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: A collaboration. The Dead Rabbits got to get strong before we make another move. I figure you're the one to make us strong. There's a lot we can learn from you.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Boyo, I'm a freebooter and a mercenary, not a teacher. I can't learn nothing from you and I can't earn nothing from you either.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: The Dead Rabbits is going to be glorious again. We're going to reign over the Points.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: And Bill Poole's Natives? What will they have to say?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Nothing. They won't have tongues left to speak.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Don't worry about what theylll have in their mouths. You think about what they got in their hands.  Listen, son... take a word from a man who was honored to fight beside your father. Temper yourself like a sword, and pay attention to balance. Anger spoils an edge.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Then you say no?

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: You see my instrument there? First notch represents two dollars and fifty cents. That's how much I got for my first kill. There are forty-eight more notches after it, and my fee has grown with each one. I can accommodate you alright, but you got to afford me. So do business with me or do it on your own.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Everything I got is still to come. So I guess it's on my own, then.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Fair enough. You'll find independence a fine thing, a fierce thing. Although I do hold money preferable to all.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Bound to.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Tammany's here to take the chill off the winter and the weight off your heart. It's Tammany can make this city a fit place, with the help and vote of all you good people...

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: We could use help here. Grab a sack.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: So I've observed.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: What if you hadn't? Think of the embarrassment. And what if you had? Consider the waste. Next time you're in a dust-up like that, think ahead and make proper plans. It'd be a grand source of revenue, whoever prevails.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Our mutual interests. That's why I want you to contact Monk Eastman.  I want you to extend a proposition. I want him to join US.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Oh, not Tammany, of course not. We could no more have him there than you. But he should throw in with the Native Americans, become aware of our Arrangement and ... well, use his influence, shall we say, to enrich us all.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: It's none of that, Bill. None of that. His independence is like a rebuke to Tammany. And an insult to you.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I should. If I'd been confident-absolutely certain--that you would have prevailed. Monk is an unpredictable power, and a figure of size. He needs to be reckoned with.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: No. He's an elemental force. Them you don't destroy. But you can contain them and use them for the good they give off.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Coal?

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: And this is your offer?

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: How do you think we'd sit as allies, Bill?

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: My thoughts exactly. Then why are you here? Because you were asked to be. You were ordered to be. And who would order me among the Natives? You? And would you follow my orders, even if they was being relayed from William Marcy Tweed himself?

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Dubious and doubtful, my friend. But your offer--pardon, the offer you bring--is the most generous that's ever been extended. I favor the terms, if not the personalities. So let us decide the way any Native American would appreciate. We'll do it the democratic way.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Citizens of the Five Points! It seems the Native Americans have come to trouble. They have grown so weak that now they seek my help. They can pay any wage I ask. But I ask you now. Even for money, should I carouse and conspire alongside a boyo like this with gristle on his knife and spittle on his chin every time his cock gets hard?

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: There. You see. I'm afraid the people have spoken.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Well, if it's a fight you want now, Bill, remember to come back with a bankroll.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: Ah, the Native Americans, is it now?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Are they coming?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: We don't want a ruckus, minister.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: Nor do I. I intended no disrespect. I'd heard the Native Americans were figures of the greatest prominence here.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Indeed they are, just for the moment. Let them come. Happy to have them. Everyone's welcome in a house of God, isn't that right, Reverend?

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: As all are welcome in heaven.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Ild like to go to heaven. Ild like to go to heaven and bite off Gabriells ear.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: You're still welcome, even with such peculiar appetites.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: But if the Natives do come, Father...

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: I'm not a priest, son ...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: ... there's no accounting for what may follow.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: I'm sure God's hand will guide us in that. Just as He guided you here at the right perfect time, with a right perfect regent. The young lady with the sunset hair. Miss ...

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Everdeane. Jenny Everdeane.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: Miss Everdeane. Step forward, please.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: And the evening's regent chooses her evening's partner.

Speaker: reverand raleigh
Dialogue: Here we make only joyful noises to the Lord.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: Now. The men, please. One by one.

Speaker: reverend raleigh
Dialogue: Next Gentleman, please.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: So you accept?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You accept to be my mort and no one else's.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: No, it's just that I didn't recognize you in the mirror. You still got some of the face the Butcher gave you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It's not the Butcher, it's the dancing. It shifts my face all around.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Maybe you'll look better later.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I will if we're together later.  And what about after that? After tonight?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I chose you just for tonight. If that's not good enough I'll go with someone else.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'll have tonight. But after this don't come to me no more till you're ready. No more.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Amsterdam!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Me.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Come on in.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I don't want to come in! You come out.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Just a damn minute.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I'm going to fight you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Oh, Jesus, Johnny, I'm tired. How about sometime else?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Now.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You want to tell me what this fight's over? Is it The Butcher? Jenny?  Alright, alright. Then tell me why like this?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: So when I lose no one will see.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Satisfied?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Satisfied? It wasn't me that's been dancing and shagging all night.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Enough.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: That's it then.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: The hell.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Goddamn it.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Goddamn you anyway.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: What's the trouble, Don?

Speaker: don whiskerandos
Dialogue: There's someone here.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: It's just a man of commerce.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: Come out with it then.

Speaker: monk eastman
Dialogue: What the hell...

Speaker: greeley
Dialogue: I may enjoy the bounty of your table and the pleasures of your company, Mr. Tweed ...

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: And the pleasures of the company provided you, Mr. Greeley.

Speaker: greeley
Dialogue: ...without the Tribune endorsing your politics.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I suppose you can at that. Take with one hand, flay with the other. Virtuels on your conscience, Horace, but Tammany's in your heart.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Pheasant.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: You killed a bull this morning. I told you to make an Arrangement with him, and you come back with his blood on your hands.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: You stand for anything if I tell you.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: What did you earn us, killing Monk?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I see it lost you a lot of God's sense, along with that eye.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: You need two eyes to see the depth, Bill. That's how we help each other. If it wasn't for me would be happy enough to plunder the Points and put the fear into people who don't know nothing else. But Bill, I'm only saying... I'm counselinm... look in the distance. You want to sit at my table, fine. But you must always remember who the host is. It's not a matter of courage welre talking. It's manners.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Fine, if you're hungry.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I've always told you, Bill. There's plenty for all, and more for us together than separate. We'll dine together sometime.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Let me put this to you, Daniel. Now that the Butcher has killed the single most prominent figure in the Five Points--a man of myth and moment--who is there to take his place?  Of course. Then what do we do about the Butcher? He's too useful to be killed, but he must be checked.

Speaker: killaran
Dialogue: It could be a police matter.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Impossible! Any cops who might have the mettle to go against the Butcher have blood ties to the gangs. They can't be trusted. And any cops that can be trusted are too craven to be any use. If Bill's to be checked, it must come from within the Points, not without.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: The Dead Rabbits did a proud job for elections. That Amsterdam boy has sand.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: That so? The last time I saw him he was under the Butcher's knife looking like a fine filet. Who else is there?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Well, the Rough and Tumble Boys over to Slaughterhouse Point. There's Country McCleesterls bunch, too, and the Plug Uglies, but there's none that have the promise of the Dead Rabbits, or the stake, neither.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: What would that be?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: The boy Amsterdam has a blood feud with the Butcher. He's sworn revenge for the death of his father, and he's got the heart to carry it forward. He'll have the skill and power soon enough.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Blood will make a man intrepid. Bring them along, then. Nurture the Rabbits with neglect. Let them roam where they like.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: And if they roam into some portion of our own revenues?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I'd tolerate a little trespassing if it was for a higher good and use. They'll cross with the Natives soon enough and keep each other occupied.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Bill's got to be a lot more than occupied.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I'll hold Bill in check. If he becomes unwieldy ... well, damn it all, Daniel, I might just have to oil up my old musket. What do you think of that, eh?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: It'd be gratifying, Mr. Tweed. Even edifying.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: But poor politics, eh? Well, we musn't have that.  I do miss those roistering days, though. Oh, and bring some of that food for the canaries.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: We ain't had no milk this week.

Speaker: native 2
Dialogue: You can have as much as you can pay for.  Anyone that's got the ned, step up with your pitchers. Any not, come back when you do.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I got ned enough for all. See? Fair enough?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: What's our rate? What do we charge?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Johnny worked it out to a nickel less than the Natives. Just till we're established. Then we raise it a penny more than now.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Raise it? Is that what you want?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You say, then.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: There'll be no paying at all this day. Or this week, neither. This is Dead Rabbits business from now on.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: We'll take ned if you got it, now or in future. But no one will go without.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Except us. You opening a charity?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: They'll pay us what they owe, in loyalty if not in cash. Tammany gives coal, we give milk.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: They can afford it.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Can't we?

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: This place is so clean it's the next thing to chaste. And safe as a convent, too.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: From the Natives, maybe. But not from us.

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: You're saying I got to worry about your mob too?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: No worries at all. You throw in with the Dead Rabbits and we'll worry about the Natives.

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: And if someone else comes along, do I pay them too?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You only pay us. We see you safe from everyone.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Leave off her. She don't want you. Not even if you could pay her.

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: Hey, just a minute.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: He can't pay. I can pay.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Maybe I should offer Johnny as a bouncer for your busy nights.

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: A bouncer! I don't know if he could bounce on a feather bed. He wants to be a character like you, is that it?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: He's got his own ideas. Too full of Tammany, maybe, but he's a fast friend.

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: But in my trade you go on your instincts. My instincts says to heed you, and my memory of your father says I'm right. We'll shake on it.  And have one of my best to seal the bargain. Megs!

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: Come here and show my new friend why we're worth special care.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You liked that old man? You would have gone with him?

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: I like anyone that pays, that's all.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Tell me what he wanted you to do.

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: He mostly wanted comforting.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I never seen hair so black. Can you take the pins out?

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: It takes so long to do back up.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Did your mother have the same color?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: What's that mark?

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: I always had it.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: And there? Is that a scar?

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: There was a baby. They cut it out.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: And that on your shoulder? That looks old.

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: Yeah, I got that when I ...

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I don't want to know when. Don't tell me about before or what you used to be, I don't want that.

Speaker: emma loss
Dialogue: What about your scars. Do you have scars?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: None I ever seen. Maybe you can find them.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Go on. I can see you later. Megs leaves, brushing past Jenny.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I couldn't decline what Mother Joyce offered. It's in the interests of business. You understand business.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Sure I do. But there's something else I still don't understand. At Sparrow's Pagoda, did you hit me, knowing it was me?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Yeah. I did.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Meantime's over.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Oh fine. That's fine. I'd be celebrating but I'm losing too much blood.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Put your head back.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: That don't work.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Put your head back I said.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: So why so sudden, then?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Sudden? Every day I see you and you complain I can't decide. Now I decide, you say it's sudden.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It's the whore did it, then.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Don't flatter yourself.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It's because you're jealous.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: It's because you didn't lie about hitting me.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Christ, I wish I had. Come here, then.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Not here. There's too much past.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: It must be morning.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I don't care, I'm not getting up.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: This is what you meant, then? It's going to be just the same from now on?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Every morning I wake up next to you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Or you don't wake up at all.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: We only just started in and you're already threatening me.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It's not a threat.  It's a declaration of love.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I prefer my kind. This kind.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What's this? Where'd you get this?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You said I was the best thief in the Five Points. But I got restless. Will you wear something I got?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What is this place?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: My jeweler's.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I don't see nobody.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: That's the best time. They're all having lunch.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You're off your head.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Don't worry. I know every house on this street. They all leave their doors open. They live like they're not in New York.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Come on. I might still be taken for a maid. But you're nobody's notion of a butler.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: The Police Commissioner lives the next street over. I was thinking of visiting him next month, but cops don't buy goods. They keep all their graft in cash.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: How's that for ten minutes?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It's a lot to fence.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I'm not going to fence it. I'm going to keep it and take it where no one will recognize it.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Where would that be?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Somewhere west. Far west. Past the Mississippi River, somewhere into that territory.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: That's a hard journey for a woman alone.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You'd be with me.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You got it all planned and straight, is that it?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Once I said I'd be with you I wanted someplace we could be together. Someplace better than here. What's the matter with that?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Nothing. Except there's no place but here for me right now. I got to settle things.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Yeah, I know, but I'm talking about settling down, not settling debts.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You don't have my obligations.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: It's a fair day's wage. We just move the people out of the building, and collect.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Who from?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Who owns the building.  Them.

Speaker: gent 1
Dialogue: I'm glad you came in force. There's half a hundred people still in there.

Speaker: gent 2
Dialogue: Maybe more.

Speaker: gent 1
Dialogue: And not one's given rent the whole year.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You live here?

Speaker: gent 1
Dialogue: No, no, of course not.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I mean in the city. A ways north, I'll bet.

Speaker: gent 2
Dialogue: Yes. Why?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: It's not just citizens in there?

Speaker: gent 1
Dialogue: Of course it is.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: with arms?

Speaker: gent 2
Dialogue: From their damned gang. Some of them live there.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Some of who?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: We didn't contract for that.

Speaker: gent 1
Dialogue: We'll pay extra for the danger.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No danger. But you will pay extra.  Let's go and greet some Natives.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Alright, then?

Speaker: gent 2
Dialogue: Very much alright. Quite a spectacle.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Oh really? Just the entertainment you favor, is it? Pardon me for a moment, gents.  You wanted to settle, you and me. That's so, isn't it? You did agree, did you not.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I did, yes.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Good, because I didn't want to act hasty. I can never tell for sure what you're thinking, and sometimes I'm not always sure what you're saying...

Speaker: gent 2
Dialogue: Excuse me, we have to finish and...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Where do you settle?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Amsterdam, what are you saying?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'm asking, where does anyone settle?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I don't know, you mean a place, a home?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: A home yes.

Speaker: gent 1
Dialogue: Excuse me, but we really must conclude.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Well, I'm saying to you then, Jenny Everdeane, welcome home.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Fine place. Room enough for all.  Get them out of here.

Speaker: gent 2
Dialogue: They'll come back looking for you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: With whose help? The Natives? They won't help these flourishing bastards even for ned.  Tell any who wants they can stay. If they can't pay rent they can join the gang. But make sure the best rooms go to us. Look around ...

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I know this building.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: These lead all under the Square, into the Brewery and out again from there. They're closed off and forgotten since the Reverend opened the mission. Pass me the candle.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: We lived in this building till she lost her seamstress work and we went to the Brewery. One day she slept so drunk she never woke and I brought her back here. Dug this myself.  Families. Give here what I gave you.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: She'll keep an eye on this for us. How about some help?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You trusting me with your treasure, then?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Just take another look at it to remind you. I can always do fine on my own.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: What's mine is yours, is that it?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I could use this, too.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You making an offering to the Reverend Raleigh?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Are you sure we can trust your mother?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: The building and how many?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: The Dead Rabbits are a wooly bunch alright.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Not just now. It's between too late and too soon. They've become a little too prominent for comfort, but they're still too small for you to soil your hands. The man who killed Monk Eastman pushing around a mob of upstarts. It's practically undignified.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Very well, and to hell as well with any plans you and I may have for growth and change and even greater reward. You'll never advance anywhere beyond the limited perimeter of your imagination.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Got to, no. But ought to.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: An invitation. To dinner.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: He never had his own cross. Thanks.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Your touch is light, but as a tracker you work awful heavy. Come ahead. Now that I met your mother, you should come and meet my father.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You should finish the stone.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It'll be finished when everything's finished. That's when helll rest. The hand that killed him is the hand that will bury him in peace.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: It was Bill killed him, not you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: With my hand on the knife.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: And his hand on yours!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: And me feeling the life go out of my father! He looked at me ... he looked at me and he swore me with his eyes. I could feel his spirit... I say I could feel it rising... flowing through the knife like blood into my own heart.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You talk like he lives in you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I don't want him to live, I want him dead! I kill Bill and I'm free of them both!

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You think you can be free that easy? You need your way so clear, and you''' use anything to clear it. Anyone, too. Me, everybody, we're all just a way for you to settle your damned ghosts.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You're part of me now, like the gang is part of me and my father both. If I can bring us to glory, then my father... like The Book says...my father can enter his house justified.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Now! Finish him now!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Our man will take him in another five. What puts you in such a hurry?

Speaker: barnum
Dialogue: I want to extend thanks and admiration not only to our two combatants today, but to their sponsors, the Dead Rabbits ...  ... and the Native Americans.

Speaker: barnum
Dialogue: Their generous support allows me to bring you this splendid exhibition. With their indulgence I'd like to remind you also of the further wonders that await you at my new Museum, located on Broadway...

Speaker: barnum
Dialogue: ... P.T Barnum's gallery of wonders from worlds natural and unnatural, from nature and from myth!  ... fists up!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Dobbs will take him this round. That'll be something. The Natives has never lost before.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Because there's never been a Dead Rabbit fighting before.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: That'll shame them thorough.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: There'll be worse than shaming. We only got the Natives in range.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Don't push the Natives too far, Amsterdam. Otherwise it'll be Tammany pushing back.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: That don't matter any more.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: It does matter, and it's going to matter even more. Tammany's the heart and future of this city. If the Rabbits is going to keep growing, we're going to have to throw in with Tammany some way.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: They got that Conscription Act from Washington keeping them busy, but they won't leave us alone forever. And the Natives is strong as they ever been!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You call that strong, John?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: This is our time now!

Speaker: barnum
Dialogue: The winner... gentlemen, please! ... the winner in the 39th round is the Dead Rabbits champion, High Water Dobbs ... please, gentlemen!

Speaker: barnum
Dialogue: Just a moment, please, gentlemen! There's a word for us all. Amsterdam promises ...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: To the death. If he can stand up to it.

Speaker: barnum
Dialogue: ... on which money, I hasten to add, may certainly be wagered. The names of the two champions are Amsterdam Vallon, here beside me, and ... and Mr. William Poole, known to all as ...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Come on, Bill! Let go of your Tammany wet nurse! My challenge, your terms.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: Don't do it, you can't do it! There's the Conscription to deal with, and elections coming, too. That's your calling now, not these ancient quarrels.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I remember it better from another time.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Your release from service, according to the terms of the Conscription Act. Keep it somewhere safe.

Speaker: draftee 1
Dialogue: Hey, tell your Papa to pass me three hundred dollars too.

Speaker: draftee 2
Dialogue: Tell him if he don't we'll come get you on our way to Gettysburg.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: No thanks owed, son. Conscription's Federal Law, and so's the $300 exemption. You might remind your father, though, that you saw me here today, minding that the law's strictly and equitably enforced.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: You see how much they like this damned law? Enforcing it's going to hurt us in elections.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: It's not my law, and not my liking, either. But Washington's always treated us with sufferance, and we must extend the same regard to them.  Boys, we are bound by honor and love of country to fight in this time of crisis!

Speaker: draftee 4
Dialogue: We're bound by our wallets and the emptiness in them, that's what!

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Boys, the union is in distress, our land is wounded deeply, our future is suddenly a frail and finite thing. We must ask ourselves how...

Speaker: draftee 5
Dialogue: Yeah, you could talk a dog off a meat wagen, Tweed. But let's see you fight!

Speaker: draftee 6
Dialogue: That'd be worth twice three hundred dollars to see!

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Holy Mother.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Daniel, between the blindness of Washington and the damned brass of Bill Poole Tammany will fall like an autumn leaf. We must take what measures we can. Attend to the Butcher. After the elections, of course. Unless you think Amsterdam will do our work for us first.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: He could at that. Then he would become a fresh concern

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Not so daunting as this.  Boys, I've just had a word with your compatriots inside, and if you show half the sand and a fraction of the spirit they have manifeste for joining this great struggle...

Speaker: outside draftee
Dialogue: Put a rope around it, Tweed, and swing in your own wind!

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Great weeping Jesus, Daniel, whatever happened to the halcyon days?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I swear that science will be the death of industry.

Speaker: killorkn
Dialogue: The telegraph moves the voter tabulation by wire faster than we can get the repeaters in and out.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Do something!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: If you'll allow me.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: There's a scheme we might try.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: You got no place among us, get the hell out of here however you come in.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: A moment please, Daniel. One moment.  And therefore no particular friend to us. What brings you here?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Opportunity. Science and opportunity.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: You got opportunities enough among your own.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I did have. But times change faster than people. Some people, anyhow. And I like to stay with the advantage.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Well, then, a Gentleman of foresight! Are you suggesting... or perhaps you're even saying... that your friend and your gang may be ... well, lagging behind the great march of history?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Something like that, yeah.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Well fine, step up to history then and tell us what you have in mind.

Speaker: boyo 1
Dialogue: I ain't goin' up there. I got my election suit on.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: This election'll be over unless we get up there.

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: "We?" This was your notion, you go up there.

Speaker: boyo 2
Dialogue: Him. He looks likely, and he ain't workin'.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: ...how much?

Speaker: boyo 1
Dialogue: A dollar.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Five dollars? Just to help us?

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: What's the pitch, Johnny? Amsterdam wouldn't like it, working with Tammany.

Speaker: boyo 2
Dialogue: Well, now, if Amsterdam wouldn't like it ...

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: He knows about it. Welre working a whole new scheme. But I won't tell him youlre helping, if that's the way you want it. And you can keep the full five. Just start climbing.

Speaker: sheeny mike
Dialogue: Where's the ned?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: He was working a Tammany job, Tammany will see to him.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: He wasn't Tammany. Not like you.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: He made the right choice.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You don't know what you're saying! You killed one of our own. One of your family!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I'll say my farewells.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You still smell like drink.

Speaker: newsboys
Dialogue: New Tammany victory! Fernando Wood elected to third term! Tammany ticket prevails by narrow margin! Boss Tweed vows Armageddon for crime!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Can't you hear the future?

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: We say the Square is the place. Let Barnum sell the tickets for a share of the price...

Speaker: native second
Dialogue: A small share.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: And the Rabbits and Natives will split the majority portion equal.

Speaker: native second
Dialogue: Who works the crowd?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Nobody. This is a day of honor. No pickpockets, no lush-rollers, nothing.

Speaker: native second
Dialogue: We got to fix positions for everyone so there won't be no other fighting. I know for fact the Roach Guards has sworn blood against the Black Birds, and the Forty Thieves don't tolerate the Chichesters.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Amsterdam will make the Butcher a fine banquet.

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: My ned's on the boy. He's got the youth, and he's got the hunger.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Is he so hungry you'll put up a hundred?

Speaker: mother joyce
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Your honor... yes, and the law of the land... lies in the balance. The Conscription Act of 1863 was handed down by President Lincoln himself ...

Speaker: crowd member
Dialogue: If Lincoln signed it, then let Lincoln fight!

Speaker: crowd member
Dialogue: Tammany's been our voice, let Tammany pay the exemption for all!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: That must be the vanguard of Barnum's army.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: This city will burn like Gomorrah.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Then we'll take what we can before it gets too hot.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I think it's past that already.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: It'll never come to that. These people ain't gang-led and they have no purpose.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Fight better and not get so mad. They're only doing what they should have done years ago. Why'd they ever think there was another way to live?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: They believed what people told them, that's all.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What people is that? The Reverend at the mission? Boss Tweed? Daniel Killoran? People like Johnny Sirocco?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: You believed Johnny.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Hell.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: And I believed you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I ain't done nothing different than what I told you, Jen.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I believed what you said abaut being with me, with me alone. But you lied to me. It's not me alone, it's just you and Bill Poole. Youlre so blood-blind you can't see nothing else, not even this!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I don't care a fine damn about what they want! It's what I want! They won't dare harm the Points, that's all I care about! Let them turn the rest of the city into hell! It's another country anyway.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: It's not a country for me, Amsterdam. I don't know about you. Will you come with me?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Not now.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Now is when I'm going. Will you come?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I don't want all this fighting to go to waste, Jen. I want to come out of it with something. And I got to be waiting for the Butcher.

Speaker: family man
Dialogue: We're with you, don't harm us!

Speaker: mob man
Dialogue: Show us your spirit and come out with us then!

Speaker: mob woman
Dialogue: And put a candle in the window to show you're one with us! Every light is a flame against the draft!

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: little girl
Dialogue: Cops has everything closed to the north, and the militia's coming.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: My Daddy don't have to die for you! Why should he fight and die for you?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I'd kill you for this.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No we ain't going to fight, but we can take something for ourselves out of this.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: I want to know who hung them bodies in the Bloody Angle. I want to address who done it.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Five thousand people in the street done it! Boss Tweed done it! Abe Lincoln done it! There's nothing you can do about any one of them but stay with us. You'll have a little of your own back.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: These riots are a gift. They...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: ... they've made everything clear, as you might say.  Are you with us, then?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Until I can get out. I'll go with you...  ...meantime.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Good. We're going for the Armory at Canal Street.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: The Armory! We'll have to beat the militia to get there.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: There's a way through the lines. Jen, did you see the cops and militia?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: I can show you from here where they are. I doubt they'll get to the Armory in force before midday tomorrow.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: We'll get there first. We'll take everything we can carry, and destroy the rest so no one else has the use of it, the militia, the Natives, nobody. Then we'll turn to real business. We'll go down to the Battery.

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: Why, we going to take a sail to Europe?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No. But we could, after this. We're going...  Are we not?

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Seems we are.

Speaker: greeley
Dialogue: They attacked me! I had every sympathy for them at first...
