Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Too much sympathy, Horace. Writing these riots were a rising against "unjust laws and unsuitable law-givers." The shame!

Speaker: governor
Dialogue: I suspended the draft at noon but the mobs only grew more virulent. It is a criminal rising of the lowest class, of the Gangsters and rabble who have been allowed by Tammany to run lawless!

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: It was Tammany and the rabble that elected you, Governor. And it's Tammany and the gangs who'll stop it. Isn't that so, Bill?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: He's here on our business and my invitation. He's already been of great help. What's the opposition strength, John?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Each candle is against you, gents.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: "Against you," sir? Don't you mean "us".

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Some of us come from those people, Mayor. I'll not deny they still claim part of me.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Which part? Perhaps your heart.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I'm sorry you find it necessary to question the loyalty of my friend here, and by extension, my own judgement. So as proof ... John, where will the mob go? What will the gangs do?  Go on, tell them what you told me.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: There's no telling about the mob. Or the small gangs. But the Dead Rabbits ... if I was Amsterdam...

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: As indeed you nearly was. Were.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: ... if I was ... I'd figure to take the Rabbits to the Armory.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Would you agree with that, Bill? Wouldn't you do the same? If you were fighting against the militia instead of beside them?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: You will have to fight beside them to take the Armory. It cannot fall into unfriendly hands.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: We're all of us swept up in a great tide of events, Bill. Have you learned to swim?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: I'm sure that Bill will do his usual splendid job. But after that ... well, I'm afraid he's grown away from us.  He shows distressing signs of... shall we say, free-thinking. Crime flourishes in chaos, and these riots could encourage Bill to overstep himself. He no longer inspires in me the same trust... well, that you might. If you can prove yourself further.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You already said in front of everyone you trusted me.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: In vital things. Would I be talking to you now otherwise? Vital things, but small things. Are you equal to greater responsibility and opportunity?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Such as what?

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Ridding me of Bill the Butcher.  He may question your loyalty to me, but Bill would never believe you had the sand to go against him. He'd never expect it. Do you have the sand?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Let him in.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Did you miss us, John?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Not a bit.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Are you here to spy?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I don't have to spy.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I know what you're doing. I told Tweed what you're doing.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You don't know what I'm doing.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You're going after the Armory.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Am I now? Why do you think that?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: 'Cause that's what I would do, and you and I think alike.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: No more. And it don't seem worth a visit to tell me something you already think I'm doing.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: There's something else alright. Tweed's arranged to kill Bill the Butcher.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Who could Tweed get to do that?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: One of his own.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: There's no one around him...

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Listen, it don't matter who, it's going to be done, that's all! Tweed ain't going to wait around for you and Bill to settle yourselves. I'm telling you so you have a chance.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Chance of what?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: A chance... a chance to do what you want. Bury the Butcher, draw what blood you got to. But you better make speed. The Natives will move on the Armory too.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: And what's any of it mean to you?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: It means whatever's left of friendship, I don't know. There's still part of me here. I don't want to see you lose everything in your life at once.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'm going to lose nothing.  If you believe me, you can stay.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: I got to go.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: So Tammany's going to kill the Butcher. That puts you and Tweed on the same side. Does that make the path clear enough to suit you?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Then you better learn to fight locking over your shoulder, Bill, because that's the only way you'll ever see it coming.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: One reason. You're my kill, Butcher. No one else is going to have you, not Tweed, not Tammany, not those pigs in the street. No one--not even you, Bill--will ever take the pleasure of your death away from me. I'd do anything to keep you for my own, even if I have to protect you.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Fine, so long as I pass you on my way.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Someone I credit.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You join with me and we fight against Tammany, fight them back and out of the Points. Then you and me can settle. But if you don't join with me, then there won't be no settlement because you'll be murdered in the street and the whole Points will be mine.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Why don't I make it easy for you, then.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Same as you're making it easy for Tweed.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Where's the Native Americans?

Speaker: rioter
Dialogue: Ain't seen them. Ain't here.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: And the militia?

Speaker: rioter
Dialogue: There's a detachment coming on from two streets over. The rest is still north of here. What are you after?

Speaker: rioter
Dialogue: The Devil himself couldn't take that place.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: That's why he sent us.

Speaker: jenny
Dialogue: Help me. Oh please help me. He's shot, we need a doctor, please help.

Speaker: detachment commander
Dialogue: Miss, we ain't a medical outfit. The main unit's ten minutes behind us, they'll have...

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Help us, we got wounded!

Speaker: guard 1
Dialogue: We can't leave the post.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Open the damn doors then! We're bad hurt!

Speaker: guard 1
Dialogue: Where's the others?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Just behind us! But I got our major here wounded so bad half his guts is out!

Speaker: guard 1
Dialogue: God, it's good to see you!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Likewise.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Move fast! We got to get out with everything we can before the militia gets here!

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: It's from the Armory Guards. That's the last before the wire went dead.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: If the Rabbits are already at the Armory, where the hell is Bill and the militia?

Speaker: killoran
Dialogue: They got to be near.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: So long as they're near, it's alright. The Rabbits can take the Armory, but they can't hold it. If Bill can get into position, he can make sure they don't get out.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Alright then, John, you pray to any God you choose that's the fact of it. If Bill thinks he can best the Natives, that is your opportunity. That is your moment.  Are you a Bible man? The Book says in Revelations, "I saw a new heaven and a new earth." If the hand of God's not on you to fulfill that prophecy, then the hand of Tweed will be. Go on and God bless.

Speaker: governor
Dialogue: I don't believe he can do it, Tweed.

Speaker: boss tweed
Dialogue: Oh, I think he can. Whether it's one man against another or a mob against the city, the mathematics remain the same. You never enjoyed the enlightenment of poverty, did you, Governor? If you had, you'd know you can always hire half the poor to kill the other half.

Speaker: militia commander
Dialogue: I can't spare the men or stand the risk! We stay fast and smoke lem out!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Tweed.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: No. There's no friends for me.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Go on, then, talk.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Come ahead then. And bring my friend's body.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Tammany's put us all in the same place. You want to get out alive?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I don't want to lose you so easy. You'll never get past the militia unless you come with the Dead Rabbits.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: I'm not forgetting where I put it.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: What's your call, Bill?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Go ahead them, give them cover! Give them some damn cover!

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Whose gang might it be?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Which way you pointing that?

Speaker: jimmy spoils
Dialogue: Any way you say. One direction could let us out, the other will let them in.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Who do you want to fight, Bill?

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: See you in the street.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: You'll have a warrior's funeral anyway, John.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: But you and me ain't settled.

Speaker: amsterdam
Dialogue: Then let's start over.
